Situation1: They have a serious conversation about financial or health decisions that require full transparency and mutual understanding.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story: I sat across from my spouse at the kitchen table, the air thick with the weight of our conversation. We needed to talk about our finances—about the unexpected expenses and the way our savings seemed to be slipping through our fingers. My spouse looked at me, expecting honesty, wanting to understand every detail so we could face this together. I wanted to be open, to share everything, but my mind kept circling back to the family I’d been helping as a volunteer. Their struggles had shaped my perspective on our own situation, but I’d promised to keep their story private. As my spouse pressed for more context, asking why I seemed so anxious about our own spending, I felt torn. I wanted to explain, to be fully transparent, but I couldn’t betray the trust of those I was helping. The urge to be a good partner clashed with my responsibility as a volunteer, and I felt the tension rising inside me, unsure which expectation I could afford to let down.
